articles.headline: Hackers Hit Twitter C.E.O. Jack Dorsey in a ‘SIM Swap.’ You’re at Risk, Too.
articles.snippet: Hackers have been targeting regular people and celebrities with the attack. Last week, it was used to hijack the Twitter account of Twitter’s C.E.O.
articles.abstract: Hackers have been targeting regular people and celebrities with the attack. Last week, it was used to hijack the Twitter account of Twitter’s C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When hackers took over the Twitter account of Twitter’s chief executive, Jack Dorsey, last week, they used an increasingly common and hard-to-stop technique that can give them complete access to a wide array of the most sensitive digital accounts, including social media, email and financial accounts.

articles.headline: In Bahamas, a Blind Father Wades to Safety, His Disabled Son on His Shoulders
articles.snippet: Against all odds, Brent Lowe escaped the wrath of Hurricane Dorian. Now the real struggle begins.
articles.abstract: Against all odds, Brent Lowe escaped the wrath of Hurricane Dorian. Now the real struggle begins.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — The roof had blown clean off. Outside, the ocean surged, swallowing the land. Brent Lowe knew he had to escape — and take his 24-year-old son, who has cerebral palsy and can’t walk, with him.

articles.headline: Trump Moves to Send Mortgage Giants Back to Private Sector
articles.snippet: A long-awaited plan from the Trump administration would return Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to the private sector, with a government guarantee.
articles.abstract: A long-awaited plan from the Trump administration would return Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to the private sector, with a government guarantee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday unveiled a long-awaited plan to end federal control of two mortgage giants that had been bailed out by taxpayers during the 2008 financial crisis and return them to the private sector.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Alan Rappeport and Lola Fadulu

articles.headline: Markets Soar on News of China Talks, but Hopes for Progress Are Low
articles.snippet: Stocks rebounded as the United States and China scheduled further discussions, but there is little sign of tangible progress.
articles.abstract: Stocks rebounded as the United States and China scheduled further discussions, but there is little sign of tangible progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to renew talks with China in the coming weeks sent financial markets soaring on Thursday, as investors seized on the development as a sign that both sides could still find a way out of an economically damaging trade war.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Hurricane Dorian Becomes a Carolina Problem With a Fierce Lashing of the Coast
articles.snippet: After assaulting the Bahamas and skirting past Florida, the sprawling storm began sweeping north through the Carolinas.
articles.abstract: After assaulting the Bahamas and skirting past Florida, the sprawling storm began sweeping north through the Carolinas.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After its deadly rampage across the Bahamas and brush of Florida, Hurricane Dorian pounded the Carolinas on Thursday as its center closed in on Cape Fear, N.C., sowing fear and worry from the elegant streets of downtown Charleston to the jigsaw puzzle that is North Carolina’s barrier islands.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: Jeffrey Epstein’s Donations Create a Schism at M.I.T.’s Revered Media Lab
articles.snippet: The proudly contrarian lab has been divided since its director disclosed that he had taken money from the disgraced financier. Its efforts at healing demonstrate lingering cultural questions.
articles.abstract: The proudly contrarian lab has been divided since its director disclosed that he had taken money from the disgraced financier. Its efforts at healing demonstrate lingering cultural questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joichi Ito gave himself some advice in 2008: “Reminder to self,” he wrote on Twitter. “Don’t invest with or take money from creeps,” although he used an earthier term.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu, Marc Tracy and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: No New School at Fort Campbell: The Money Went to Trump’s Border Wall
articles.snippet: The Pentagon is diverting $62.6 million from the construction of a new middle school at Fort Campbell, meaning that 552 students will continue to cram themselves in at an aging school.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon is diverting $62.6 million from the construction of a new middle school at Fort Campbell, meaning that 552 students will continue to cram themselves in at an aging school.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For almost two decades, families at Fort Campbell, the sprawling Army base along the Kentucky-Tennessee border, have borne the brunt of the country’s war efforts as a steady clip of troops with the 101st Airborne Division and from Special Operations units deployed to Afghanistan and Iraq.

articles.headline: The Polaris RZR, an Off-Road Thrill That Can Go Up in Flames
articles.snippet: The Polaris RZR, a vehicle for recreational use, has been linked to scores of fires and four deaths. But its maker insists it is safe.
articles.abstract: The Polaris RZR, a vehicle for recreational use, has been linked to scores of fires and four deaths. But its maker insists it is safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost two years, James Bingham’s off-road vehicle had provided endless fun on camping and hunting trips in Idaho. The vehicle, a four-seat Polaris RZR, could zip across the sand hills at up to 80 miles an hour.

articles.headline: ‘We’re at War’: A Covert Social Media Campaign Boosts Military Rulers
articles.snippet: After protesters were killed in Sudan, an obscure Egyptian company ramped up a covert influence operation that spanned the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.abstract: After protesters were killed in Sudan, an obscure Egyptian company ramped up a covert influence operation that spanned the Middle East and North Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Days after Sudanese soldiers massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Khartoum in June, an obscure digital marketing company in Cairo began deploying keyboard warriors to a second front: a covert operation to praise Sudan’s military on social media.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Nada Rashwan

articles.headline: Hiring Slowed in August, but Wage Gains Accelerated
articles.snippet: The figures show that the economy continues to add jobs but at a more modest pace as the trade war intensifies and global growth slows.
articles.abstract: The figures show that the economy continues to add jobs but at a more modest pace as the trade war intensifies and global growth slows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The great American jobs machine is flagging, showing signs of its age and damage from an intensifying trade war with China and a slowing global economy.

articles.headline: New Google and Facebook Inquiries Show Big Tech Scrutiny Is Rare Bipartisan Act
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans at both the federal and state levels are uniting to investigate the power of Big Tech and, potentially, to rein in the dominant companies.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans at both the federal and state levels are uniting to investigate the power of Big Tech and, potentially, to rein in the dominant companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a major force uniting America’s fiercely partisan politicians: big technology companies. Democrats and Republicans at the federal and state levels are coming together to scrutinize the power of the Silicon Valley giants and, potentially, to rein them in.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Investigates California Emissions Pact That Embarrassed Trump
articles.snippet: The investigation escalates a standoff between President Trump, California and the auto industry over one of his most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.
articles.abstract: The investigation escalates a standoff between President Trump, California and the auto industry over one of his most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has opened an antitrust inquiry into the four major automakers that struck a deal with California this year to reduce automobile emissions, according to people familiar with the matter, escalating a standoff over one of the president’s most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Coral Davenport
